Defining the logarithm at small heights

Mar 5, 2019

In the previous post, we explicitly computed values of the - and -local logarithms . In this post, I want to return to conceptual theory, and ask the following question: is there a map ? This is not a question with a trivial answer: the Rezk logarithm takes values in -local spectra, and lifting it to the -local setting is, in general, pretty hard. Naturally, you might wonder: why would one expect such a map to exist? Such a map exists for both and (the former being easy to construct, the latter being due to Ando-Hopkins-Rezk). The example of doesn’t indicate very much about why this “integral” logarithm exists, but is a good prototype: the key property used in this latter case is that is somehow built using -divisible groups, and these have a good theory of isogenies; this allows for the construction of the “Atkin operator” (which we already implicitly used in the previous post) that saves the day. I’ll elaborate more on this below. Coming back to : one expects there to be an integral logarithm for , because this is somehow built from -divisible groups. Morally speaking, Lurie’s theorem (which we discussed here) says that is the “even-periodic refinement of the moduli of -divisible groups of height ”. This is more precisely reflected in homotopy theory by the Hopkins-Ravenel smash product theorem. Since I will be working with -divisible groups, I will now -complete everywhere, and I will really mean when I write .

With this convention, is already -local, and so constructing the integral logarithm is just the definition of the -local logarithm. (This is why the case of isn’t very enlightening.) Let’s now try to construct a map . The Rezk logarithm supplies us with two maps and . The targets of these maps in turn map to , and so we can ask if the corresponding square commutes. The answer is no (when is life ever this easy?) — but there is a map for which the composite agrees with the map .

Why does this map exist, and how is it constructed? In order to answer the first part of this question, we need to recall Rezk’s formula for the -local logarithm on Morava -theory. We know that is either a wedge of Morava -theories (if ) or is homotopy equivalent to the homotopy fixed points for some finite subgroup of the Morava stabilizer group acting on the height Morava -theory associated to the formal group of the supersingular point of . Let’s suppose that , so that is equivalent to only one copy of . The map factors through . The Rezk logarithm is -equivariant, and the map is just the -fixed points of this map. Let’s restrict ourselves to just understanding the map .

In this case, Rezk proves the following (see here as well): let denote the universal deformation (over ) of the formal group of the supersingular curve over (at ), and for , let denote the formal group of height over . If is a subgroup of order of , then there is a map from the Lubin-Tate ring to the Lubin-Tate ring with -level structure, classifying the quotient formal group ; this is the statement that is another universal deformation of the formal group of the supersingular curve, i.e., that universal deformations are “closed under -isogenies”.

For and fixed , define an additive operator (the “Hecke operator”) as follows:

Then, Rezk’s formula states that if is a space, then the map is given on an element with (as is the case for every element when is a sphere) by

More explicitly, this states that

where denotes the infinitesimal component of the -torsion group scheme . Note that the operator appearing in is precisely the classical th Hecke operator which is defined via the correspondence .

I claimed above that there is a map which upon composition with gives . Algebraically, this is the statement that there is a map such that . The above formulae show that we need

The operator defined by the sum above (i.e., ) is called the Atkin operator, and is denoted by . (We already implicitly used this map in the previous post.) Since and are defined via maps of spectra, we would like to say that is actually induced from a map of spectra.

To do so, we will use Theorem 2.9 here (or rather, the obvious adaptation of that result to periodic ). The problem of constructing a spectrum map now reduces to constructing a map purely on the level of algebra. In order to define this map, we need to define an intermediate moduli problem: let denote the ordinary locus of the moduli stack of elliptic curves, and let denote the moduli stack of elliptic curves along with a closed immersion which is an isomorphism on the connected component of the identity. This is a -torsor over , and if we define , then the cited reference states that there is an isomorphism . To define the desired lift of to , we therefore need to simply define as a continuous -equivariant map . The formula for given above already does that for us! In this case, would be the -divisible group of the universal elliptic curve over , and would be defined in the same way as before; this relies on the fact that the ordinary elliptic curves are closed under -isogenies.

We’ve now got our desired map which ensures that the composites and agree. In particular, since is -local (remember, we -completed everywhere!), we obtain an “integral logarithm” . This map is defined such that the fiber of is equivalent to the fiber of the map (in other words, and sit inside a pullback diagram), which in turn is related on homotopy to the spectrum of the Atkin operator . There’s apparently a lot of deep number theory that goes into understanding this spectrum, and it would be interesting to use some calculations from there to understand the integral logarithm . The calculations we did in the previous post boil down to working with ; we showed, for instance, that and are both killed by .

How can we use this obtain an integral logarithm for ? Recall that the Hopkins-Ravenel smash product theorem says that -localization is smashing. In the course of proving it, one finds that -localization being smashing is equivalent to the statement that is the geometric realization of the cosimplicial diagram defined by . The functor preserves limits (see here), so in order to define a map , it suffices to define a map of cosimplicial objects. The first level is easy: this is just going to be the Rezk logarithm . The next layer, however, is scarier: we need to define a map , but the uncompleted (i.e., non--localized) smash product strikes fear into my heart.

Some of fears may melt at height : it is in fact true that is the geometric realization of the cosimplicial diagram defined by (so that defining a map reduces to constructing a map of cosimplicial spectra). Why is this true? As I said above, the smash product theorem is equivalent to the statement that is the geometric realization of the cosimplicial diagram . This is because -localization is smashing if and only if is the geometric realization of the cosimplicial diagram . In order to prove the statement made at the beginning of this paragraph, it therefore suffices to prove that has the same Bousfield class as .

To see this, consider the finite etale cover at (at , one uses the cover ). Since this map is etale and is affine, this corresponds to an -map of -rings, where is Landweber exact. This map is an etale cover, in the sense that ; this implies the concrete statement that a -module is zero if and only if it is zero after base-changing up to . In particular, and have the same Bousfield class. We are therefore reduced to showing that has the same Bousfield class as . This is because is Landweber exact and -periodic, so we win by Corollary 1.12 of this paper of Hovey’s.

We’ve now shown that ; from the moral point of view that (really, I mean ) is the global sections of an even-periodic refinement of , this is an analogue of the fact that there is a formally etale map . As I said above, defining a map now reduces to constructing a map of cosimplicial spectra. Although we won’t prove exactly this, we will obtain a map as a consequence of the following two observations:

  • The story I told above for defining the Atkin operator, and therefore the integral logarithm for , works for the global sections of any derived stack arising via Lurie’s theorem (which we discussed here): the condition in Lurie’s theorem amounts to being “closed under -isogenies”. The formulae and above are exactly the same, except now and can run over all integers between and the height of .
  • Let denote the global sections of the even-periodic refinement of the formally etale map . (Making this precise takes some technical maneuvering.) One might expect this spectrum to be , but the best one can say in general is that there is an -ring map . We may then consider the geometric realization of the cosimplicial diagram defined by ; note that if , then this is the geometric realization of the diagram , which we showed above is . We claim that, in fact, . Here’s a sketch. There is a map , and to obtain an equivalence between their totalizations, I just need to note that there are compatible maps which assemble into a morphism of cosimplicial objects. This forces to be .

One can run the same story at any height, and this gives a map , which can be extended to a map . This is very cool, and raises numerous interesting questions. For instance, the chromatic convergence theorem states that , and so one can ask if the maps are compatible as varies. It is not at all clear from the above description that this is actually the case — everything we did was very height-specific. I’ll return to this question in a later post, but let me briefly mention the plan of attack. Although we didn’t do it this way, the map can be constructed as a map of cosimplicial objects, and so to get compatibility as varies, one would somehow like to construct compatible -maps . What we will (roughly) do in the next post is construct a map between Morava -theories for any fixed finite and any , but where classifies deformations of a formal group over a big perfect field (in particular, it does not classify deformations of the Honda formal group law). Unfortunately, I don’t think that the maps we’ll construct will be compatible as varies (so in particular, we won’t be constructing a map ).
